map_node.indicator_name: Children < 5 Years Old Living in Poverty

dataset.how_calculated: Number of children less than 5 years of age living in poverty in a geographic area divided by the number of children less than 5 years of age living in a geographic area.
Number of children less than 5 years of age living in poverty in a geographic area.

link_data_node.linkDataPagetext: The "Link Data" function shows associations between environmental health data at the neighborhood level using <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Scatterplot" target="_blank">scatterplots.</a> The points represent x and y values for each NYC neighborhood. The pairs of indicators available for scatterplots were chosen because previous research suggests that one may either directly or indirectly cause or contribute to the other. Because the data being charted are <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Ecological_Study" target="_blank">ecological</a> and not individual level, and because many factors contribute to the health of a population or environment, the patterns seen in these charts do not necessarily represent the underlying causal relationship.

info.x_axis_title_reg: Children under 6 years with elevated blood lead levels (BLL)
info.y_axis_title_reg: Children < 5 Years Old Living in Poverty
info.info_name: Children under 6 years with elevated blood lead levels (BLL)
info.info_how_calculated: Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 5 mcg/dL or greater, divided by the total number of children less than 6 years old who were tested for lead poisoning in a given year; expressed as cases per 1,000 tested. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the rate of children newly identified with blood lead levels at or above a certain level reported by the Health Department in other publications. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
info.info_source: New York City Healthy Homes Program

info.y_axis_title_reg: Children < 5 Years Old Living in Poverty
info.info_name: Children tested for lead by age 3 years
info.info_how_calculated: Number of children born in New York City to New York City resident mothers who were tested for lead poisoning before the age of three years, divided by the number of children born in New York City to New York City resident mothers turning three years old; expressed as percent. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.
info.info_source: New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics,New York City Healthy Homes Program
